awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Malleability of Trait-Based Face Judgments
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program and SBE's Social Psychology program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Jonathan Freeman at New York University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the malleability of trait attributions from faces. People are able to quickly and automatically abstract information from faces, including broad trait information such as whether a face seems trustworthy or not. This process has long assumed to be due to some innate mechanisms, with developmental evidence showing that there is strong consensus about whether a face looks trustworthy or dominant from a very young age. These judgments of trustworthiness have potentially serious downstream consequences, such as hiring decisions, electoral success, and the assignment of the death penalty. 

This project is focused on exploring the extent to which our trait judgments, specifically centered around trustworthiness, could be acquired and affected by implicit associations between face information and positive and negatively valenced behaviors. The primary aim of this research is to test the malleability of trait impressions from faces in response to information involving associated positive and negative behaviors. To address this research question, this project aims to 1) Examine whether an arbitrary face feature can be associated with positive or negative behaviors, resulting in a subsequent shift in evaluation of faces that contain that feature. Across a number of different measures such as payment in an economic trust game, implicit priming measures, and mousetracking, this project aims to test the extent to which newly learned features and their associations are integrated with the natural trustworthiness of faces to affect evaluations of trustworthiness; 2) Test whether a similar implicit learning paradigm could impact propotypical representations of trustworthy and untrustworthy faces. In this aim, people will participate in a training wherein faces that have features typically denoted as trustworthy associated with negative behaviors and faces that are typically demed as untrustworthy are predominantly associated with positive behaviors; 3) Determine whether implicit learning mechanisms can result in the formation of stereotypes for completely novel categories of faces. This project takes an integrative approach that incorporates the findings from the perceptual learning literature about implicit learning and maximizing the efficacy of associative learning into the realm of social face perception and the effects of conceptual knowledge on perception. This research potentially provides a novel understanding of the malleability of trait impressions and might elucidate the cognitive mechanisms behind the formation of stereotypes. This approach would test the current understanding of trait impressions and the notion that they might be innate, fixed, and do not require experience or a social learning component. The results of this research, particularly the line of research investigating the effects of counterstereotyping on our pre-existing conceptions of trustworthiness, could be used to inform interventions targeted on reducing implicit race and gender bias.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As we navigate the social world, we automatically judge others’ faces based on various traits such as their trustworthiness or competence. This process is automatic and happens very quickly, within 100 milliseconds. Trait judgments from faces have severe potential consequences, as they are predictive of outcomes such as hiring decisions, election outcomes, and legal decisions governing life and death sentences. These appearance-based biases occur despite a lack of correspondence between these features and actual personality. Because of these potentially severe consequences, it is important to determine the extent to which these biases are malleable and flexible to experience and new, incoming information.

 If, for example, our implicit learning systems are flexible, then counterstereotyping paradigms might be able counteract even these consequential biases. In a set of 4 studies, we first establish that these face stereotypes are arbitrary, as completely novel stereotypes can be formed based on the co-occurrence between specific features and behaviors associated with trustworthy or untrustworthy behaviors. By associating specific face features predominantly with either trustworthy or untrustworthy behaviors, we establish that our implicit learning systems are sensitive to incoming information that co-occurs with specific features. These newly learned stereotypes affect hiring decisions, implicit evaluations, and these cues dynamically interact with pre-existing trustworthiness cues to resolve in a final trustworthiness evaluation, incorporating both newly-learned and long-held trustworthiness cues. Thus, our trait perceptions are flexible to experience and arbitrary feature-behavior associations can impact perceptions of trustworthiness to a similar extent to that of pre-existing trustworthiness cues.

Having established the flexibility of our trait perceptions, we aimed to use a similar training to impact the lifelong associations we have with trustworthiness face features. There is a well-established set of features that govern trustworthiness judgments. For example, those with more upturned mouths are perceived as more trustworthy, while those with a furrowed brow are perceived as less trustworthy. In another set of studies, we trained people to associate those who had trustworthy faces with predominantly untrustworthy behaviors and those with untrustworthy faces with predominantly trustworthy behaviors. In effect, for the trained group, we created a counterstereotype for this set of trustworthiness face features. In an economic trust game, a mock hiring procedure, and in automatized implicit evaluations, the trained group showed no significant difference in in evaluations for faces very high and low in facial trustworthiness, thus eliminating the bias based on trustworthiness. Although it is unknown how long the effects of such training might last, these studies demonstrate that even long-held trait attributions from faces are malleable to learning and experience.

In a final set of studies, we apply similar training to act as interventions against face-based biases with potentially serious real world consequences. Individuals who look untrustworthy are assessed with harsher penalties in the legal system and are more likely to be assigned the death penalty. We enacted the same counterstereotyping training as above to attempt to reduce this biased reliance on facial trustworthiness. In two studies, participants rated a set of real world prisoners (who had received either a death penalty or life in prison sentence) on their trustworthiness and they rated the harshness of the penalties each should receive given that they committed the same crime. For the controls, trustworthiness predicted the penalty received, but trustworthiness was not predictive of the sentences for the trained group. For the punishment severity ratings, the severity of punishment was predictive of the actual sentence, but this relationship was weakened in the trained group.

We enacted a similar training regarding facial attractiveness. There is a well-established halo effect of attractiveness, where those who are more attractive are thought of in higher esteem in many domains, including competence. Using the Judgment Bias Task, which is a measure that uses a mock procedure in accepting students into an honors society, we demonstrate that a version of our counterstereotype training was able to reduce preferential treatment to more attractive applicants. Taken together, these studies show promise that even a relatively short training can affect our trait perceptions of faces and that face-based biases that have potentially consequential real-world outcomes can be intervened upon.

Overall, this research has demonstrated the malleability of our trait-based attributions from faces, as we flexibly update these attributions based on the co-occurrence between specific face features and trait-related behaviors. Future research can leverage these findings to longer, more intensive interventions that could curb these biases on a longer temporal scale. Further, in principle, the potential benefits of such training could extend to broader social categories such as age, gender, and race.
